message.content: Sleet is a form of precipitation that occurs when snowflakes partially melt as they fall through a layer of warm air and then re-freeze into ice pellets before reaching the ground. This means that sleet is made out of water that is cold. Option (A) is incorrect because vapor refers to water in its gaseous state. Option (B) is incorrect because sleet is not hot, it is typically associated with colder temperatures. Option (C) is incorrect because sleet is not in liquid form, it is in the form of ice pellets.

This question requires basic knowledge of meteorology and the process of sleet formation. Sleet is a type of frozen precipitation that falls to the ground as ice pellets. It is formed when raindrops freeze into ice pellets before reaching the ground. Therefore, sleet is made out of water that is cold. Option (A) is incorrect because vapor refers to water in gas form, not sleet. Option (B) is incorrect because hot water would not freeze into ice pellets. Option (C) is incorrect because liquid water would not freeze into ice pellets.

This question requires basic knowledge about the formation of sleet. Sleet is formed when raindrops fall through a layer of freezing air near the earth's surface and become supercooled, meaning they become colder than the freezing point but remain in liquid form. As the supercooled raindrops continue to fall, they freeze into ice pellets, creating sleet. Therefore, the water that makes up sleet is cold. Option (A) is incorrect because vapor refers to the gaseous form of water. Option (B) is incorrect because hot water would not freeze into ice pellets. Option (C) is incorrect because liquid water would not freeze into ice pellets.
